rubric.name: Technical Accuracy and Logical Relationships
rubric.description: Technical concepts must be described accurately with correct logical relationships between ideas. Avoid presenting sequential or complementary processes as competing alternatives.
rubric.evidence: User corrected 'rubric generation versus RL fine-tuning' and insisted on accurate description of how rubrics capture what users value rather than domain constraints.

rubric.name: Context-Appropriate Register
rubric.description: Language should match the contextâ€”research writing requires academic terminology and framing rather than marketing or commercial language.
rubric.evidence: User explicitly rejected 'core innovation' stating 'This is my research project, not a product.'

rubric.name: Emphasis Aligned with Core Purpose
rubric.description: Writing should emphasize what genuinely matters to the user's goals rather than peripheral features, even if those features exist.
rubric.evidence: User redirected emphasis from 'ability to switch between models' to fine-tuning with LoRA using rubric-based reward functions for user alignment.

rubric.name: Direct Communication
rubric.description: Communicate ideas directly without unnecessary formulaic transitions or procedural framing phrases. Start with substance rather than meta-commentary.
rubric.evidence: User rejected 'The approach works as follows...' in favor of direct description of the system.

rubric.name: Precision in Terminology
rubric.description: Use precisely the right terms and framings even when similar concepts might seem interchangeable. Small differences in meaning matter.
rubric.evidence: User corrected 'domain constraints' to 'what the user values in their writing' despite the concepts being related.
